item.title: Russia report: UK considers tougher security laws after criticism by MPs
item.description: Ministers are set to face questions in the Commons after MPs said the UK "underestimated" the threat of Russia.

item.title: Trump concedes pandemic to 'get worse before it gets better'
item.description: The president also asked all Americans to wear face coverings, saying they show "patriotism".

item.title: Belarus election: Snatched from the streets in Europe's 'last dictatorship'
item.description: Activists and journalists are being rounded up and jailed in Belarus ahead of next month’s elections.

item.title: Coronavirus: Business struggles, passport backlog and the Joe Wicks effect
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus outbreak this Wednesday morning.

item.title: Coronavirus: UK passport application backlog reaches 400,000
item.description: Reduced staffing to allow social distancing is one reason for the mounting backlog, a minister says.

item.title: Anti-Semitism: Labour whistleblower lawsuit expected to be settled
item.description: The party is being sued for defamation by ex-staff who spoke out last year about handling of complaints.

item.title: QAnon: Twitter bans accounts linked to conspiracy theory
item.description: The social media site says it is taking action to limit behaviour that could lead to "offline harm".

item.title: Hong Kong activist Joshua Wong: ‘A few cars are following me’
item.description: Joshua Wong believes he is now being followed, after the new security law was passed by China.

item.title: Sydney police 'asked woman to remove tampon' in strip-search
item.description: A review into police conduct during five controversial strip-searches has called for an official apology.

item.title: Toronto 'Chair Girl' spared jail for 2019 balcony stunt
item.description: A video of Marcella Zoia throwing a chair from a Toronto high-rise onto a highway went viral.

item.title: Home insulation scheme must guarantee high-quality work, say campaigners
item.description: Homeowners using a energy efficiency grant must be protected from bad quality work, campaigners say.

item.title: Prince George photos mark seventh birthday
item.description: The future king flashes a smile at the camera in photos taken by his mother, the Duchess of Cambridge.

item.title: The Papers: 'Welcome to Londongrad' and Pompeo attacks WHO
item.description: Wednesday's papers focus on the release of a long-awaited report into Russian interference in the UK.

item.title: Moon bears: Korean campaigners call for farm closures
item.description: Animal rights campaigners are calling for the closure of hundreds of moon bear farms.

item.title: Birmingham designer creates PPE for men with turbans
item.description: A designer has created PPE for men who wear turbans or have long beards.

item.title: AO.com boss: 'Behave as if your mum is watching'
item.description: John Roberts, founder of white goods retailer AO.com, shares his business advice for CEO Secrets.

item.title: Lockdown Brits splurge on tea, biscuits and a good book
item.description: People working from home have spent heavily on tea, coffee, biscuits and new books.

item.title: Afrobeats: New chart names genre's top artists in the UK
item.description: J Hus, Burna Boy and NSG top the list, which will be announced on BBC Radio 1Xtra on Sunday.

item.title: Coronavirus: What jobs are available post-lockdown?
item.description: The world of work is changing thanks to Covid-19 - which sectors are hiring and which are struggling?

item.title: Coronavirus: How Joe Wicks' fitness workouts 'changed my life'
item.description: As the Body Coach ends his live morning workouts, people explain what the sessions have meant to them.

item.title: Olympics postponement leaves UK firms in limbo
item.description: With the Tokyo Olympics delayed to 2021 due to Covid-19, UK firms have seen their plans disrupted.

item.title: How deep are Britain and China's economic ties?
item.description: The two countries' growing relationship includes nuclear power projects, foreign students and trade.

item.title: How singer Samantha Crain rebuilt her career after a life-changing accident
item.description: US singer Samantha Crain lost the use of her hands after three crashes. Here's how she recovered.

item.title: Coronavirus in India: 'PM Modi, please make men share housework!'
item.description: After India's lockdown revealed some hard truths about housework, one woman set out to fix the gender gap.

item.title: Russia report: The unanswered questions
item.description: What are the questions still to be answered following the MPs' report on Russia?

item.title: Coronavirus: Did 'herd immunity' change the course of the outbreak?
item.description: What drove the government's thinking in the crucial stages of the coronavirus outbreak?

item.title: 'The prize is the Premier League' - all to play for as Championship concludes
item.description: What is still to be decided when the 2019-20 Championship season finishes on Wednesday?

item.title: 'Courageous' Aston Villa out of relegation zone with one game left
item.description: Aston Villa move out of the Premier League relegation zone with one game to go after Trezeguet hits a superb winner against Arsenal.

item.title: 'It makes it even more special' - Henderson joy at receiving trophy from Dalglish
item.description: Liverpool captain Jordan Henderson says receiving the Premier League trophy from Reds legend Sir Kenny Dalglish "makes it even more special".

item.title: Archer says sport is 'fickle' and reports racist social media abuse
item.description: England's Jofra Archer says sport is "fickle" and reveals he has reported racist abuse on social media before the third Test against West Indies.

item.title: Football off-season: Eight days without games - is it the shortest ever?
item.description: Football fans do not need to worry about an off-season, with only eight days without games between the two Premier League campaigns.

item.title: Coronavirus vaccine: Might it have side-effects?
item.description: Questions about how a vaccine might work and other coronavirus topics.

item.title: Coronavirus UK map: How many confirmed cases are there in your area?
item.description: Key graphics explaining how coronavirus has spread in the UK and the government's response.

item.title: Coronavirus: How does the 'eat out to help out' scheme work?
item.description: Diners will get money off their bill on certain days to help kickstart the hospitality industry.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules for face masks or face coverings?
item.description: England will follow Scotland by making face coverings compulsory in shops.

item.title: Coronavirus: What powers do the police have?
item.description: Coronavirus lockdown rules are changing across the UK, but who is responsible for enforcing them?

item.title: Coronavirus: Where can I go on holiday? A guide to destinations
item.description: As people in the UK get the green light to go abroad again, here's a look at what's in store for travellers.

item.title: Coronavirus: How are indoor gyms and pools going to open?
item.description: As lockdown eases in England, more activities are being allowed but how are customers being kept safe?

item.title: Coronavirus: Young people on benefits double in lockdown
item.description: Experts fear it may take up to four years for youth unemployment to recover from the pandemic.

item.title: Coronavirus vaccine: When will we have one?
item.description: About 200 groups of medical researchers around the world are working on a vaccine for Covid-19.

item.title: Coronavirus: What closes in a local lockdown?
item.description: Local authorities will be given the power to take action on coronavirus outbreaks in their area.

item.title: Does getting coronavirus make you immune?
item.description: What you need to know about how the immune system works.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the UK's travel rules and which countries can you visit?
item.description: New agreements mean people entering the UK from certain countries will not have to quarantine.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are social distancing and self-isolation rules?
item.description: Social distancing and lockdown rules are changing in England - but what can you now do?

item.title: Coronavirus: What's the risk on transport?
item.description: People are being asked to return to work, meaning public transport could become more crowded.

item.title: Coronavirus: Can my boss force me to go back to work?
item.description: The advice about going back to the workplace in England will change from 1 August.

item.title: Coronavirus: How does contact tracing work?
item.description: People who have been in close contact with someone found to have Covid-19 are now being traced.

item.title: Bowling alleys and casinos to reopen - what will they look like?
item.description: Bowling shoes could become a thing of the past says one firm, as it prepares to reopen in August.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules on weddings?
item.description: Many weddings were cancelled during lockdown, while some will have to change to meet the new rules.

item.title: Coronavirus: How the financial shockwave is affecting jobs and money
item.description: With the UK facing a severe economic downturn, what is the outlook for our personal finances?

item.title: Unemployment rate: How many people are out of work?
item.description: The number of people claiming benefits has surged, but the unemployment rate has barely moved. Why?

item.title: Coronavirus cure: What progress are we making on treatments?
item.description: Teams around the world are looking into medicines for Covid-19 and scientists are starting to discover what works.

item.title: The Mongolian Rooney, the thief, and the fightback
item.description: A fake agent stole $6,000 from a teenager with ambitions to become a footballer - then he fought back.
